reporting-org.narrative: Centro de Aprendizagem e Capacitação da Sociedade Civil

title.narrative: Igual: Rights and Democracy

description.narrative: The Igual program will support formal and informal, established and emerging, national and local Civil Society Organizations (CSOs) in Mozambique to encourage collaboration, information sharing and synergy building to advocate for respect for human rights and citizen engagement in democracy to promote accountability and transparency.

participating-org.narrative: Centro de Aprendizagem e Capacitação da Sociedade Civil
Centro de Aprendizagem e Capacitação da Sociedade Civil

description.narrative: Cabo Delgado, Mozambique

title.narrative: Baseline Study IGUAL
Technical notes results framework
2021 Narrative Report

description.narrative: Executive summary of PEA conducted

title.narrative: 1000. Human rights defenders, sexual minorities, women and children in conflict zones have access to mechanisms of defense and protection of human rights
1000.3 Proportion of women affected by conflict aware of mechanisms to report human rights abuses

description.narrative: This indicator will report results of surveys conducted with women affected by conflict in the Zambezi Valley and Cabo Delgado. The survey will be brief and anonymous and ask only of respondents are aware of human rights and mechanisms to report violations human rights. While women will be approached through snowball or random sampling methods, members of sexual minorities will only participate in focus group discussions organized in partnership with community based organizations that work with these groups so as not to endanger this vulnerable population. Specific mechanisms already in place in each region will be identified as part of the baseline study and woman respondents will be asked about these mechanisms and any others that are similar. During mid-term and endline evaluations, focus group discussions will also be conducted with survey respondents their understanding of the mechanisms in more detail.

comment.narrative: As was the case in indicator 1000.2, the baseline study was not able to collect systematic data on this indicator from sexual minorities. As such, the data presented here refers to the proportion of women in each region that say they are aware of mechanisms to report human rights abuses.

As this is an outcome indicator, it will be measured only at baseline, midline, and endline. It is not expected to change over the course of one quarter, and therefore the team has not set quarterly goals. At midline, the goal will be for approximately 85% of women in both Cabo Delgado and the Zambezi Valley to be aware of mechanisms for reporting human rights abuses.

title.narrative: 1000.1 Human right defenders' perceptions of safety

description.narrative: This indicator will consider the proportion of human rights defenders that report feeling safe carrying out their work. Their safety assessment will be based on their responses to a survey, inspired by the USAID survey that assesses safety of activists, adapted to the Mozambican context as needed. The survey will assess safety of human rights defenders along dimensions of: freedom of speech, freedom to receive and disseminate information, right to be protected by law, right to observe trials, right to legal defense of their rights, prevalent attitudes towards human right defenders in law, political parties, the media and the public, access to national and international protection networks

comment.narrative: Data based on qualitative data from interviews conducted with civil society organisations and others that act in defense of human rights and those that defend human rights in Mozambique. Only 3 of the 35 interviews conducted said that they had no safety concerns related to carrying out their activities.

As these indicators are related to longer-term programme outcomes, we do not expect to see changes in them within the period of just one quarter. Especially in the first semestre of the programme, which had a slower inception phase than planned, programme staff and partners were not expected to create changes in these indicators within a short period of time. This indicator will only be measured again during the mid-term evaluation, at which time the goal will be for 12% of human rights defenders to feel safe operating in their typical work (an increase from the 10% at baseline).

title.narrative: 1000.2 Proportion of reported cases of human rights abuses committed against sexual minorities and women and children in conflict zones in which a perpetrator is identified

description.narrative: This indicator will aggregate data on reported human rights abuses again sexual minorities and women and children in the Zambezi Valley and Cabo Delgado. Then information about where a perpetrator has been identified in each case will be collected. The final indicator will report the proportion of reported cases in which perpetrators are identified.

comment.narrative: Data reported here refers to the proportion of women in Cabo Delgado and the Zambezi Valley that have reported a human right violations in the last 12 months. Due to low cultural acceptance of the LGBTI community in Mozambique today, it is not safe to collect representative data, as demanded by this indicator, on this population. This information can only be gathered through qualitative means, which will be pursued through the IGUAL programme's partnership with LAMBDA in the coming 6 months. Data was collected from households, but can only be disaggregated by gender. As the baseline study shows, the vast majority of those that say they report cases of violence report them to local leaders (neighborhood chiefs, religious leaders, or community leaders). As such, it is not possible to systematically collect reliable data on case follow-up or closure. This information can only be obtained on a qualitative basis through interviews, which will be pursued at midline and endline.

As these indicators are outcome indicators, the team does not expect changes on a quarterly basis. These indicators will be measured again only during the mid-term and final evaluations. As they are farther along the Theory of Change, the assumption is that the programme will need to work for a few years before we start to see results in these indicators. At mid-term, the programme goal will be to make progress in terms of the proportion of women in Cabo Delgado and the Zambezi Valley that report human rights abuses, and particularly in the proportion that report using a formal channel, such as police, attorney general, or courts. The mid-term goal will be for the proportion of women in Cabo Delgado reporting human rights abuses to increase to 36% and the proportion of women reporting human rights abuses in the Zambezi Valley to increase to 41%.

title.narrative: 2100. Increased influence of women and youth in formulating policies and programs that aim to increase or provide resources for development of youth and women
2100.1 No. of CSOs/groups/networks working with women and youth to promote their capacity to formulate policies and programmes that will provide resources for development of women and youth

description.narrative: This indicator will be self-reported by grantees, and will ask grantees to report how they are actively promoting women's and youth engagement in policy formulation and programmes. IGUAL staff, especially the gender and social inclusion specialist, will assess the approaches and also look at how these approaches take place on the ground during monitoring visits. Based on this evaluation, this indicator will report the number of organisations that actively promote participation of women and youth in policies and programmes that provide resources for the development of women and youth. As usual, the indicator will be disaggregated by organisation type and region.

comment.narrative: Livaningo, FAA, SAMCom Mocuba, AMPDC, LAMBDA, CIP

title.narrative: 2100.2 Proportion of women and youth that feel that they have influenced policies or programs focused on development opportunities for women and youth

description.narrative: Data for this indicator will also be collected through surveys with women and youth. Surveys will ask women and youth about any decision-making processes they have been involved in related to development opportunities for women and youth. If they have been involved in any such processes, they will be asked if they think their participation influenced the final outcome. The indicator will aggregated data and report the proportion of individuals surveyed who feel that they influenced policies and programmes related to development opportunities for women and youth, by type of individual and region. This information will be triangulated by information from focus group discussions with those individuals willing to participate during the midline evaluation. The midline evaluation will also include focus group discussions with women and youth that participate in activities of IGUAL grantees

comment.narrative: This indicator will be measured on an anual basis. Systematic data, like that which appears for the baseline figure, will only be collected at midline and endline. The IGUAL programme will work with partners to conduct focus group discussions and interviews on a more limited basis each year in order to help us have an idea for the direction in which this indicator is moving.

title.narrative: 2300. Local governance more participatory and inclusive
2300.2 Proportion of women and youth that believe their participation in local government will bring about positive changes in their lives

description.narrative: This indicator will draw on survey results with women and youth. At baseline and midline this will be a random or snowball sample. Annually, these surveys will be conducted with a random sample of women and youth that participate in activities of IGUAL grantees. Respondents will be asked if they participate in any local government process and if they believe that their participation will make a difference. Their answers will be triangulated with results of focus group discussions conducted during the midterm evaluation. The indicator will aggregate responses from all respondents and report on the proportion of respondents that feel that their participation will bring about a positive change in their lives. The final data will be disaggregated by respondent type and region.

comment.narrative: Data represents the proportion of women that believe participation in democracy will improve their lives
Indicator will be measured on an annual basis.

title.narrative: 2300.1 No. of CSOs/groups/networks building capacity of women and youth to participate in local government processes

description.narrative: This indicator will collected data from a combination of sources. On a quarterly basis, grantees will be asked to self-report what they do to support women's and youth participation in local government processes. The GESI officer will assess how much these actions effectively promote active participation of women and youth. Annually, some women and would will participate in the grantee beneficiary survey and they will be asked if the grantees have activities to prepare them for participation and if these activities did help them prepare. Finally, this information will be triangulated with information collected from focus group discussions conducted during the midterm evaluation. This indicator will aggregate the number of CSOs that actively working to promote women and youth participation in local government processes, by region.

comment.narrative: Livaningo, FAA, SAMCom Mocuba, AMPDC, LAMBDA, CIP
Contracts were not yet signed with partners, so while selected organisations included in the baseline continued to do their work, they are not counted in this quarter's data

title.narrative: 1400. Increased action to protect and expand civic space
1400.1 No. of CSOs/groups/networks involved in actions to protect or expand civic space

description.narrative: This indicator will be self-reported by grantees. Grantees will report if they are involved in actions to protect or expand civic space and describe these actions on a quarterly basis. This indicator will aggregate the number of organisations involved in such actions and report by type of organisation and region.

comment.narrative: MISA, LAMBDA, CDD
The programme aims to create more spaces for collaborative advocacy and action involving as many grantees as possible in order to protect civic space.
Continuation of the 3 CSOs working in to protect civic space at baseline

title.narrative: 1400.2 Proportion of IGUAL grantees that perceive positive changes (protection, expansion) of civic space

description.narrative: This indicator will be based on self-reported grantee data supplemented by key informant interviews. On a quarterly basis, in addition to reporting whether they have been involved in actions to protect civic space, grantees will report whether they perceive improvements (protection, expansion) of civic space. This indicator will aggregate data from grantees to show the proportion of organisations that perceive positive changes in civic space, by type of organisation and region. During some monitoring visits, IGUAL staff will also interview grantee representatives that are familiar with the protection of civic space to understand in more details what changes have occurred. This information will be used to provide context in annual analytical reports published in IATI.

title.narrative: 1300. Increased action to improve accountability and reduce impunity for HR violations
1300.2 No. of CSOs/groups/networks reporting increases in the efficacy of their advocacy efforts with the justice administration system

description.narrative: This indicator will be self-reported by grantees and these grantee reports will be validated by IGUAL staff. On a quarterly basis, grantees will be asked whether the think their advocacy efforts with the justice administration system have become more effective. The IGUAL communications officer will help define elements of strong advocacy campaign and grantees will self-assess on this scale. Once a year, the communications officer will also look at the grantee's campaigns and assess their efficacy. On a quarterly basis, this indicator will aggregate the number of organisations that think their advocacy efforts with the justice administration system have improved, by type of organisation and region. On an annual basis, the indicator will also include the number of organisations that IGUAL believes have improved their advocacy capacity, by type of organisation and region.

comment.narrative: Indicator measures the change in effectiveness of CSO efforts to engage with the Justice Administration.
As the programme has just started and partners have begun to implement projects this quarter, the programme is not expecting improvements in advocacy so quickly.

title.narrative: 1300.1 No. of CSOs/groups/networks engaged in lobbying the justice administration system

description.narrative: This indicator will be self-reported by grantees. On a quarterly basis, grantees will report whether they have lobbied any party involved in the justice administration system, and describe their lobbying effort. The indicator will aggregate the number of organisations by type of organisation and region

comment.narrative: MISA, ROSC, Girl Child Rights

Continuation of the work that the 3 organizations working with the Justice Administration were doing at baseline. In future quarters the programme will support additional organisations in engaging with the the Justice Administration

title.narrative: 2200. Legal framework and electoral processes influenced by civil society with a view to making them transparent, fair and inclusive, especially for women and youth
2200.2 No. of CSOs/groups/networks advocating for changes in the legal framework and electoral policies

description.narrative: This indicator will ask grantees to self-report in their quarterly reports if their activities or campaigns advocate for changes in the legal framework and electoral processes. They will also be asked to describe these actions. This indicator will aggregate the number of organisations that advocate for changes in the legal framework or electoral processes by type of organisation and region.

comment.narrative: CIP, SAMCom, IMD
Organisations selected for partnership with IGUAL continued their work, but as they did not receive financing during this period, they are not counted in the indicator.

title.narrative: 2200.1 No. of changes to the legal framework and/or electoral processes that improve transparency, fairness, and inclusion

description.narrative: This indicator will aggregate data from a number of sources, including reviews of legislation pertaining to electoral processes, done by CESC; grantee monitoring reports in which grantees will describe changes to the legal framework or electoral processes of which they are aware. This information will be collected annually. This information will be supplemented by an extensive legislative review conducted during the midline evaluation. The indicator will aggregate the number of changes to the legal framework or the electoral process that improve transparency, fairness, and inclusion, disaggregated by whether they are framework or process changes.

comment.narrative: On average, less than 1 reform has occurred each year in recent history. While election periods tend to enable a greater number of revisions, the political context in Mozambique means that it is unlikely there will be regular changes. The programme may hope for changes in enforcement, or rules, at local levels to ensure participation in provincial and district elections.

title.narrative: 1200. Support mechanisms for victims of human rights violations created and/or strengthened
1200.2 No. of IGUAL grantees involved in mechanisms outside their local area to support victims of human rights violations

description.narrative: This indicator aims to understand how many IGUAL grantees participate in protection networks that support victims of human rights violations, whether they are local, national, or regional networks. Grantees will self-report whether they are involved with such networks and which type of network is it. This indicator will aggregate the data and report how many grantees are involved in protection networks by type of organisation, region, and type of network.

comment.narrative: Organisations that are part of RMDDH or actively or other international networks that provide help to victims of human rights abuses: CDD, ROSC, Observatório de Mulheres, AMPDC, Girl Child Rights, PROMURA, Muleide

Continuation of the 3 CSOs involved in reporting and responding to abuses in the region of Mozambique at baseline. As the programme develops new response mechanisms in the coming quarters, it is expected that additional organisations will be involved in such mechanisms
Organisations were not yet funded by IGUAL, so while they continued to do their work, it was not counted in this indicator

title.narrative: 1200.1 No. of support mechanisms used/known by grantees for victims of human rights violations

description.narrative: This indicator will ask grantees to report on the number and name (description) of support mechanisms for victims of human rights abuses that they are aware of. Grantees will report this information quarterly. To supplement this information, local activists in each region will be interviewed and asked about existing support mechanisms. As the focus of this programme is mechanisms in programme regions, these will be the primary sources of data, but they may be supplemented by relevant reports published by entities such as Human Rights Watch. The indicator will aggregate data and report on the number of support mechanisms that exist, by region.

comment.narrative:
Suggestion to revise this indicator to measure the number of mechanisms used by community members, especially women. This is how it is currently reported. The mechanisms included in the baseline are:
Neighborhood chief, community court, family, religious leaders (Cabo Delgado), IPAJ (Vale de Zambézia).

Target and actual are the same as the baseline value. During the first quarter of the programme, the programme focused on supporting CSOs and discussing potential collaborative mechanisms to respond to human rights abuses, but it was not expected that these mechanisms would be known and functional within one quarter.

title.narrative: 1100. Increased awareness, denunciation and resolution of cases of human rights violations
1100.2 Proportion of human rights defenders, sexual minorities, women in conflict zones that think human rights reporting systems are effective

description.narrative: This indicator will aggregate data from surveys conducted with human rights defenders and women in conflict zones - the same survey instrument that assesses awareness of mechanisms. At baseline this will draw from a random or snowball sampling method. Information will only be collected from persons of sexual minority groups following identification of grantees or community based organizations that work with the population and can facilitate this interaction. If respondents report that they are aware of mechanisms, they will also be asked what they think these mechanisms should do to help victims and if they think the mechanisms do that (why/why not). Data will be collected on an annual basis so this is not an overly burdensome indicator. During the mid-term evaluation, key population groups that interact with the IGUAL grantees will also be asked to participate in focus groups discussions to triangulate information and explore the topic of efficacy of human rights reporting systems. The indicator will aggregate information and report the proportion of people that think the protection mechanisms are effective, by type of individual and region.

comment.narrative: Is discussed in the comments for indicators 1000.1 - 1000.3, it was not safe to collect systematic and reliable data on human rights defenders or sexual minorities. As such, the proportions above indicate the proportion of women in Cabo Delgado and the Zambezi Valley that feel that whistleblowing mechanisms are effective or very effective.

As an intermediate outcome indicator, this will be measured on an annual basis. This will enable the IGUAL programme to see where partners could focus their efforts to have a greater effect on whistleblowing mechanisms. This indicator will be measured in the systematic way it was measured again only at midline and endline. However, in the interim IGUAL will work with partners to conduct focus groups and interviews with a limited number of participants in order to continue to collect data and update this information on an annual basis.

title.narrative: 1100.1 No. of CSOs/groups/networks working on reporting human rights violations

description.narrative: This indicator will ask grantees to self-report in their quarterly reports if their activities or campaigns are related to promoting reporting of human rights violations. The indicators will aggregate the number of organisations working on increasing reporting of human rights violations by type of organisation (formal, informal, network) and region

comment.narrative:
The baseline value includes the organisations that IGUAL decided to fund that were already working in this area. This indicator will show both the areas in which IGUAL-funded projects are working (specifically reporting human rights abuses), and will also show progress as the IGUAL programme aims to encourage a larger number of organisations to engage with reporting human rights abuses in order to strengthen the RMDDH.
Financed organisations working in this area prior to receiving IGUAL funding: Girl Child Rights, MISA, Women's Observatory, ROSC, CDD

This target refers to the number of selected grantees that already work on reporting human rights abuses. As the original plan was to begin financing these grantees in the first trimestre of 2021, the goal was to have 5 funded grantees working on reporting human rights abuses during this period.

As IGUAL did not actually start financing these partners in the first quarter of 2022, as planned, they will not enter into this indicator this quarter. However, contracts began in the second quarter.

title.narrative: 2000. Increased citizen participation and representation with a focus on women's and youth priorities in governance and policy spaces and processes
2000.2 # of oversight mechanisms that specifically address gender and youth issues

description.narrative: This indicator will count the number of oversight mechanisms developed to ensure womens' and youths' priorities are considered and their participation encouraged in governance and policy spaces and processes. Examples of mechanisms: rules/policies/regulations in national / provincial assembly, national / provincial procurador

comment.narrative:
Secretary of State for Youth and Employment; - Ministry of Gender, Children and Social Action; - Offices for the Care of Women and Children Victims of Domestic Violence; - Institute for Legal Sponsorship and Assistance; - National Human Rights Commission (CNDH) and National Commission for the Advancement of Women (CNAM). In Parliament, relevant internal structures were created, such as the Social Affairs Commission and the Parliamentary Offices for Women and Youth.
Important to note here that based on interviews conducted, while these mechanisms exist and are more or less enforced at the national leve, they are not enforced at the local level. As such, progress toward this indicator may not necessarily involved a greater number of oversight mechanisms, but greater enforcement of the existing mechanisms at local levels.

To be measured again during the midline evaluation. Important to note that progress toward this indicator may involved greater enforcement and better oversight using these existing mechanisms, and not a greater number of mechanisms.

title.narrative: 2000.3 Proportion of individuals that participate in processes to monitor or contribute to the decentralization process (disagreggated by youth, women and other marginalized groups and region)

description.narrative: This indicator will consider youth, women, and marginalized groups that participate in decentralization promotion activities (or are aware of decentralization laws). The indicator will report the aggregate number of women, youth, and marginalized groups that participate in these activities by region. At baseline, this will come from a sample of women and youth in specified districts. At midline IGUAL will also collect information directly from grantees. Grantees that work to monitor or contribute to decentralization will be asked to report, by type of individual, the number of people that participate their decentralization activites.

comment.narrative: These survey respondents are also of the opinion that the level of citizen participation in government processes has improved in the past year, and especially so with the introduction of decentralisation efforts.

Quarterly targets consistent with baseline value of the indicator. Indicator will be measured again at midline, but will not be measured quarterly and the team does not expect to see changes in the indicator on a quarterly basis.

Goal aligned to the indicative goal submitted with the results framework and approved as part of the Inception Report. The team would like to reflect upon this goal, given the results of the baseline report, and possible revise it.

title.narrative: 2000.1 # of laws, policies and strategies blocked, adopted, or improved to promote womens' and youths' active citizen participation

description.narrative: This indicator will count the number of laws, policies, and strategies blocked, adopted, or improve that consider women and youth engagement. For our purposes, citizen participation includes laws, policies, and strategies that promote womens' and youths' voice, agency, leadership, and representative participation in decision making processes in public, private and civic sphere.

comment.narrative: Value remains the same as baseline. Indicator will be measured again at midline, at which time we hope to see 9 or 10 policies in place, which could include newly introduced policies at local levels.
For outcome indicators, we maintain the quarterly targets at the baseline value, as they indicators will not be measured on a quarterly basis.

title.narrative: Improved leadership, management, and performance capacities of CSOs to mobilize action and campaigns on issues of human rights, democracy, and governance
3100.3 Proportion of CSOs/groups/networks that increase their leadership, management, and thematic knowledge

description.narrative: IGUAL staff will conduct a needs assessment of each grantee at the beginning of their contract. Based on this assessment, grantees will receive a tailored capacity building programme. As these assessments have not yet been conducted, it is difficult to tell if there will be a lot of overlap between topics covered in capacity building sessions. In principle, the goal of this indicator is to measure changes in knowledge about leadership, management, thematic knowledge with a standardized assessment that IGUAL staff will conduct each year. If they tailored capacity building sessions are quite diverse, this may not make sense, and will be re-visited following the first capacity assessments. Regardless of the assessment conducted by IGUAL staff, grantees will also self-report, annually, if they think their knowledge about leadership, management, and thematic topics has improved. Following whatever kind of assessment is conducted, this indicator will report the proportion of grantees that have improved their knowledge and the proportion of grantees that feel that they have improved their knowledge, by organisation type and region.

comment.narrative: Increases in thematic and technical knowledge will come in the following quarters after the programme has begun more of the capacity-building components.

title.narrative: 3100.1 No. of CSOs/groups/networks trained on institutional, technical, and thematic topics

description.narrative: This indicator will be collected by IGUAL staff. Each time IGUAL conducts or supports a capacity building or mentoring session for grantees, they will report internally on the type of training, the grantee receiving training, and some other basic information. To cross check the data, grantees will also be asked to report what kinds of training they receive each quarter. This indicator will report the number of organisations that receive training each quarter by type of organisation, region, and perhaps topic of training

title.narrative: 3100.2 No. of CSOs/groups/networks that receive funding from IGUAL to support capacity development efforts

description.narrative: This indicator will count the number of organisations supported by the programme. It is expected that all organisations will receive some kind of capacity development through the programme in addition to receiving funds. The indicator will count the number of organisations that receive support each quarter and report on the number of unique organisations financed by IGUAL at the end of each year, by organisation type and region.

title.narrative: # of women led CSOs using a Gender and Social Inclusion lens during all phases of the programming cycle with specific attention to youth.
Knowledge produced and shared about effective approaches to influencing policy and practice in the areas of human rights and democracy
3200.1 No. of studies or best-practice documents published or shared by CESC or IGUAL grantees

description.narrative: This indicator will be self-reported by grantees and supplemented by information collected among IGUAL staff. Each quarter grantees will be asked if they published any studies or shared any best-practice documents (they will be asked to share the document or the study). IGUAL staff will also keep track of studies or best-practice documents that the programme shares with grantees or related to the areas of human rights, democracy, and governance. This indicator will aggregate data and report the total number of studies or best practices documents published or shared, by type of document

comment.narrative: The programme planned to finalize the baseline study and the political economy analysis this quarter, but due to delays in contracting in addition to delays in data collection due to violence in the north of Mozambique, these studies were not finalized during this quarter.

The team planned to publish more studies, one on the situation of women in Mozambique and the other on how to engage with youth in the programme regions during this quarter. We were not able to do this, but we did finalize the baseline study and the political economy analysis, missing from last quarter.

title.narrative: 3200.3 No. of CSOs/groups/networks that say they have adapted new approaches based on best practices shared through IGUAL programming or networks supported by IGUAL

description.narrative: This indicator will be self-reported by grantees and will ask, each quarter, if the grantees have adapted a new or different approach to their organisational management, their activities, or they advocacy as a result of best practices shared by IGUAL. The indicator will aggregate these answers and report the number or organisations that have adapted new approaches based on best practices shared by IGUAL, disaggregated by type of organisation and region.

title.narrative: 3200.2 No. of learning events held as part of the programme that consider effective approaches to influencing policy and practice in areas of human rights and democracy

description.narrative: This indicator will keep track of learning events held as part of the programme. This may include events to gather grantees that are part of the same pro-accountability initiative, events to discuss specific topics related to the programme, or events that aim to consider the programme's theory of change with grantees and discuss the programme's progress towards outputs and outcomes. Grantees will be asked if they participated in any learning events each quarter, but the main source of data for this indicator with be IGUAL's activity monitoring system in which staff report any learning events in which they participate as part of the IGUAL programme. The indicator will report the number of events held, disaggregated by audience (national or regional)

comment.narrative: Two regional learning events were planned this quarter. As contracts with partners were not signed until this quarter, an orientation workshop was held to introduce the partners to IGUAL and the results framework of the programme, but it was not possible to hold learning events at this early stage.

title.narrative: # of times that CSOs succeed in creating space for CSO demands and positions through agenda setting, influencing the debate and/or creating space to engage.

comment.narrative: Goals for this indicator will increase in the coming quarters, following the inception phase of the programme

title.narrative: Increased effectiveness of CSO interventions to promote change through vertical and horizontal pro-accountability initiatives, including media, academia, the state, and private sector entities, around issues of human rights, democracy, governance
3300.3 No. of CSO/groups/networks utilizing pro-accountability initiatives to produce or share evidence that inform advocacy campaigns in a timely manner

description.narrative: This indicator will be based on self-reported grantee data. Grantees will report whether they have participated in any activities with a pro-accountability initiative to produce evidence for an advocacy campaign or to share evidence for an advocacy campaign. Grantees will be asked to share the numbers of times they've done so and describe the evidence they produced or shared. The indicator will count the number of grantees that have (a) produced evidence and (b) shared evidence using a pro-accountability initiative to inform an advocacy campaign. Data will be disaggregated by organisation type and region.

comment.narrative: We are in the progress of establishing potential avenues for collaboration among the partners, and should consolidate these discussions in the coming quarters.

title.narrative: 3300.2 Proportion of CSOs/groups/networks that perceive improvements in the quality and effectiveness of advocacy campaigns launched through pro-accountability initiatives

description.narrative: This indicator will collect self-reports from grantees asking if the PAIs in which they participate have helped them improve (a) the quality and (b) the effectiveness of their advocacy campaigns. The indicator will be reported in two sub-sections, to show the proportion of grantees that have seen improvements in the quality and effectiveness of their campaigns. Data will be disaggregated by type of organisation and group.

comment.narrative: Again, we do not expect partners to improve their advocacy campaigns within the inception phase of the programme, but future quarters will reflect more progress towards this indicator.

title.narrative: 3300.1 No. of pro-accountability initiatives supported by IGUAL (disaggreaged by vertical/horizontal, formal/informal, mixed civil society and other actors)

description.narrative: This indicator will draw on information from IGUAL's activity monitoring system as well as financial and contractual records to count the number of pro-accountability iniciatives that the programme supports. This support may include creation of the initiative, financial assistence for specific activities from the initiative, engagement in strengthening a certain part of an iniciative through work with a grantee, etc. IGUAL staff will be asked to keep track of the PAI the programme supports, and this will be validated by information from grantee monitoring reports that describe actions the grantee has taken with PAI.

comment.narrative: During the orientation workshop, partners started to discuss potential ideas for collaboration. We hope to consolidate these discussions in the coming quarter.

title.narrative: # of advocacy initiatives carried out by CSOs, for, by or with their membership/constituency at sub-national level

comment.narrative:
MISA conducted advocacy initiative as part of their efforts to bring attention to World Press Freedom day.
CDD continued continuous campaign to raise awareness about human rights defenders in Mozambique through it's network, RMDDH
